data: {"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3312276,"name":"jimfl014","username":"jimfl014","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/d78d45/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-02-18T15:26:15.415Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eWe have a PG71 motor/transmission powering our shooter lift; however it back drives.  If we use a \u003cspan class=\"abbreviation\"\u003ePID\u003ctemplate class=\"tooltiptext\" data-text=\"Proportional Integral Derivative\"\u003e\u003c/template\u003e\u003c/span\u003e loop to keep it stable could it burn out the motor as it is brushed?\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2024-02-18T15:26:15.415Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":88,"readers_count":87,"score":42.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":455210,"topic_slug":"pg71-in-a-pid-loop-to-control-backdrive","display_username":"jimfl014","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28441,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pg71-in-a-pid-loop-to-control-backdrive/455210/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3312987,"name":"Joe Ross","username":"Joe_Ross","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joe_ross/{size}/37_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-19T17:10:00.056Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eThe fact that it brushed vs brushless has little impact on whether it burns up theoretically. Practically, in \u003cspan class=\"abbreviation\"\u003eFRC\u003ctemplate class=\"tooltiptext\" data-text=\"FIRST Robotics Competition\"\u003e\u003c/template\u003e\u003c/span\u003e, it does have some impact since many \u003cspan class=\"abbreviation\"\u003eFRC\u003ctemplate class=\"tooltiptext\" data-text=\"FIRST Robotics Competition\"\u003e\u003c/template\u003e\u003c/span\u003e brushless motors are larger and produce more torque at a given voltage then the 775 motor in the PG71. They also have built in current limiting to protect against failures. But a NEO 550 is pretty easy to burn out.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt what voltage does the arm not backdrive? You can compare that voltage to the locked rotor tests here to see whether it’s safe to have a \u003cspan class=\"abbreviation\"\u003ePID\u003ctemplate class=\"tooltiptext\" data-text=\"Proportional Integral Derivative\"\u003e\u003c/template\u003e\u003c/span\u003e commanding that voltage for long periods of time. \u003ca href=\"https://motors.vex.com/other-motors/am-775\"\u003ehttps://motors.vex.com/other-motors/am-775\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2024-02-19T17:10:00.056Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":69,"readers_count":68,"score":18.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":455210,"topic_slug":"pg71-in-a-pid-loop-to-control-backdrive","display_username":"Joe Ross","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://motors.vex.com/other-motors/am-775","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":4}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":65,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pg71-in-a-pid-loop-to-control-backdrive/455210/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3313062,"name":"jimfl014","username":"jimfl014","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/d78d45/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-02-19T18:52:16.699Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eThanks for the reply Joe.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ethe arm backdrives at all positions.
